awd_titl_txt: Race, Ethnicity, and Place Conference and Pre-Conference Workshop: Mapping and Empowerment
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the 2023 Race, Ethnicity, and Place Conference (REP) and its pre-conference workshop. The biennial REP meetings bring together diverse groups of scholars to encourage and facilitate research in geography and related scientific disciplines. Through a focus on mapping as a tool for empowerment, especially among racial, ethnic, and other minorities, the 2023 REP pre-conference workshop examines justice and equity issues within the discipline. In addition to social science research and teaching, the conference and workshop seek to promote greater participation of historically underrepresented groups within the discipline of geography and to support the professional development of minority graduate students as well as early and mid-career faculty through mentoring, networking and program development.

The REP 2023 conference advances research and teaching of mapping perspectives by recruiting a cadre of new scholars—geography graduate students and early and mid-career faculty—from a broad range of institutions (community colleges, liberal arts colleges, and research universities).  The conference focuses especially on the role of mapping in representing and promoting diverse voices, experiences, and knowledge within the classroom, in research endeavors and through public pedagogy. Conference participants examine how cartography may be used in curricula, research and in the public realm as an important tool in recruiting students, future scholars, and other professionals from traditionally marginalized groups and to advance geography as an inclusive discipline that seeks to advance equity. The conference and workshop are vehicles for strengthening and disseminating knowledge regarding alternative research methods, to increase and strengthen resources available to underrepresented scholars, to support graduate students and to aid faculty to be better mentors. The conference integrates new participants through active recruitment and engagement, by designing strategic panels and keynotes to attract a broader audience, and by offering a pre-conference mentoring and professional-development workshop for early-career faculty and advanced graduate students, especially from underrepresented groups. Responding to national workforce needs, the conferences advances goals of training early-career scholars in cartographic skills and geospatial analysis. The conference and workshop also facilitate new collaborative relationships and sustainable networks across educational institutions, governments, and civil society organizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Race, Ethnicity, and Place (REP) Conference has served for over twenty years as an important focal point for academic research on issues of race and ethnicity as well as a critical gathering place of support and solidarity for underrepresented scholars in geography and other related disciplines. The objective of NSF support was to innovate and expand the scope of the 2023 REP Conference and Pre-Conference workshop through: 1) Recruiting new scholars and build stronger collaborations—primarily from HBCUs and other MSIs along with geographical practitioners in government and civil society —thereby broadening diversity in participation with respect to race and ethnicity, research approaches, career stages, and institutional locations; 2) Creating a space where attendees could actively work to diversify the narratives, experiences, and knowledge production incorporated into geographic learning as well as explore critical cartography as a form of public pedagogy and activism beyond traditional, academic and industry definitions of cartography; and 3) Continuing to enhance diversity in the discipline of geography (and beyond) by continuing a program of mentorship, support and networking for diverse scholars, especially graduate students, and early career scholars of color.

The 12th bi-annual Race, Ethnicity, and Place Conference took place October 11-13, 2023 at the Elliott School in the George Washington University, and the pre-conference workshop was held in the same location on October 11, 2023. The conference was a collaboration between George Washington University, Texas State University, Towson University, and Kent State University in conjunction with the Mid-Atlantic Division of the American Association of Geographers.

The conference brought together over 275 participants, over half of whom were from groups historically underrepresented in academia. Of these, 89 were students, and 186 were non-students. Among non-students 76% were faculty from various institutions of higher education ranging from community colleges to R1 universities. The remaining 24% were from governmental and non-governmental organizations. The day-long workshop immediately preceded the conference and was attended by 22 early career scholars from across the United States. Attendees included Ph.D. students, Ph.D. candidates, adjunct faculty or lecturers, and tenure-track Assistant Professors. The Early Career Scholars had the opportunity to engage with and learn from eight senior scholars with expertise in critical cartography and the use of mapping as a tool in engaged scholarship. They were also given information and advice on professional development from professionals in the field including a Program Director from NSF, a Vice-President of a professional geography association and a University President.

The two days of the conference involved 133 paper presentations and 12 panel sessions, on topics as diverse as geographies of refuge, bordering, immigrant communities, diasporas and indigenous communities; environmental justice, food justice, healthcare justice, housing and gentrification, socio-spatial justice, workforce justice and climate justice; the differential impacts of diseases on minority groups, as well as Critical GIS, community engagement and mapping. Featured panels were inspired by the pre-conference workshop theme of Mapping and Empowerment, as well as related themes of social justice, diversity, and inclusion. The featured panels allowed for in-depth discussions on race and ethnicity, racial inequalities, teaching to diverse intersectionalities and using mapping as a tool for justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion (JEDI)-related research.

We integrated new participants, designed strategic panels and keynotes, and offered a pre-conference mentoring and professional development workshop for early career professionals at MSIs. The pre-conference mentorship workshop support and networking for diverse scholars created a productive forum for scholarly exchange and promoted diversity in the discipline of geography and related fields.

Complex issues of race and ethnicity need cross-disciplinary collaboration that combines various theoretical, ontological, epistemological, and methodological approaches addressing the topic at multiple scales of analysis. The 2023 REP conference, together with the pre-conference workshop, broadened participation of scholars and put into conversation distinct research approaches to the study of race and ethnicity that rarely engage or intersect intellectually. This served as a catalyst for more synergetic research, and ultimately a deeper understanding of issues of race, ethnicity and diversity. Furthermore, promoting the increased diversity of scholars, particularly from underrepresented groups, will encourage the proliferation and quality of scholarship on these topics.

NSF funds enabled the continuation of an on-going effort to diversify the field of geography and make inclusion its top priority. The sessions, speakers, and pre-conference workshop all served as a new catalyst for promoting diversity in recruiting, support, retention, promotion, and success in the discipline and beyond. NSF funds expanded the opportunities to establish and sustain peer support networks among faculty and students at HBCUs and other MSIs along with geographical practitioners in government and civil society. These efforts were intentional at making better architects of geography as well as geospatial science programs that offer effective guidance on the development of a more diverse and inclusive scientific community.
